canonical_explanation.text: Electric current is the rate of flow of electric charge through a conductor. The SI unit of current is ampere (A). Potential difference is the work done per unit charge in moving a charge between two points, measured in volts (V). Ohm's law states that the potential difference across a conductor is directly proportional to the current flowing through it, provided the temperature remains constant (V = IR). The resistance of a conductor depends on its length, cross-sectional area, material (resistivity), and temperature. Resistors can be combined in series (R = R₁ + R₂ + ...) or parallel (1/R = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ + ...). The heating effect of electric current is given by Joule's law: H = I²Rt. Electric power P = VI = I²R = V²/R, and electrical energy is measured in kWh (1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J).
rules: Electric current I = Q/t, unit: ampere (A).
Potential difference V = W/Q, unit: volt (V).
Joule's law of heating: H = I²Rt.
Electric power: P = VI = I²R = V²/R, unit: watt (W).

questions.question_text: The SI unit of electric current is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of electric current is the ampere (A). It is defined as the rate of flow of electric charge, where 1 ampere = 1 coulomb of charge flowing per second (1 A = 1 C/s).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volt is the unit of potential difference. Ohm is the unit of resistance. Watt is the unit of power. The SI unit of electric current is the ampere (A).

questions.question_text: Electric current is defined as the rate of flow of:
questions.explanation_correct: Electric current is defined as the rate of flow of electric charge through a conductor. Mathematically, I = Q/t, where I is the current in amperes, Q is the charge in coulombs, and t is the time in seconds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While current involves the movement of electrons in metallic conductors, it is formally defined as the rate of flow of electric charge (I = Q/t), not specifically electrons or protons. In electrolytes, both positive and negative ions carry the charge.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of potential difference is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of potential difference is the volt (V). The potential difference between two points is 1 volt when 1 joule of work is done in moving 1 coulomb of charge from one point to the other (1 V = 1 J/C).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ampere is the unit of current, ohm is the unit of resistance, and coulomb is the unit of charge. The SI unit of potential difference (voltage) is the volt (V).

questions.question_text: An ammeter is connected in a circuit in:
questions.explanation_correct: An ammeter is always connected in series with the component through which current is to be measured. This is because all the current flowing through the circuit must pass through the ammeter. An ammeter has very low resistance so it does not significantly affect the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An ammeter must be connected in series, not in parallel. If connected in parallel, it would create a short circuit due to its very low resistance. A voltmeter, on the other hand, is connected in parallel.

questions.question_text: A charge of 10 C flows through a conductor in 5 seconds. The current flowing through the conductor is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using I = Q/t = 10 C / 5 s = 2 A. The current flowing through the conductor is 2 amperes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using the formula I = Q/t, we get I = 10/5 = 2 A. Option A incorrectly multiplies Q and t. Option C incorrectly divides t by Q. Option D incorrectly adds Q and t.

questions.question_text: A voltmeter is connected in a circuit in:
questions.explanation_correct: A voltmeter is always connected in parallel across the component whose potential difference is to be measured. A voltmeter has very high resistance so that it draws negligible current and does not disturb the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A voltmeter must be connected in parallel, not in series. If connected in series, its high resistance would drastically reduce the current in the circuit. An ammeter is connected in series; a voltmeter is connected in parallel.

questions.question_text: Ohm's law states that:
questions.explanation_correct: Ohm's law states that the potential difference (V) across a conductor is directly proportional to the electric current (I) flowing through it, provided the temperature and other physical conditions remain constant. Mathematically, V = IR, where R is the resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ohm's law is V = IR, not V = I/R, V = I + R, or V = I - R. The potential difference is directly proportional to the current, with resistance as the constant of proportionality.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of electrical resistance is the ohm, denoted by the Greek letter omega (Ω). 1 ohm is the resistance of a conductor when a potential difference of 1 volt produces a current of 1 ampere through it (1 Ω = 1 V/A).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Volt is the unit of potential difference. Ampere is the unit of current. Watt is the unit of power. The SI unit of resistance is the ohm (Ω).

questions.question_text: A wire of resistance 10 Ω is stretched to double its length. Its new resistance will be:
questions.explanation_correct: When a wire is stretched to double its length, its length becomes 2l and its area becomes A/2 (since volume remains constant: Al = 2l × A'). New resistance = ρ(2l)/(A/2) = 4ρl/A = 4R = 4 × 10 = 40 Ω. The resistance increases by a factor of 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When a wire is stretched, both length and area change. Since volume is conserved, doubling the length halves the area. R = ρl/A, so new R = ρ(2l)/(A/2) = 4 × (ρl/A) = 4 × 10 = 40 Ω. The resistance quadruples, not doubles.

questions.question_text: If the potential difference across a resistor is 12 V and the current through it is 3 A, the resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using Ohm's law: R = V/I = 12 V / 3 A = 4 Ω. The resistance of the conductor is 4 ohms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using Ohm's law R = V/I = 12/3 = 4 Ω. Option A incorrectly multiplies V and I. Option C incorrectly adds V and I. Option D incorrectly subtracts.

questions.question_text: The resistance of a conductor depends on its:
questions.explanation_correct: The resistance of a conductor depends on its length (l), cross-sectional area (A), and the material it is made of (resistivity ρ). The formula is R = ρl/A. Resistance increases with length and decreases with area. Temperature also affects resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resistance depends on three factors: length (directly proportional), cross-sectional area (inversely proportional), and the nature of the material (resistivity). It does not depend only on one factor or on the applied voltage.

questions.question_text: The resistivity of a material depends on:

options.text: The nature of the material and temperature

questions.explanation_correct: Resistivity (ρ) is a property of the material itself and depends on the nature of the material and its temperature. It does not depend on the dimensions (length or area) of the conductor. Different materials have different resistivities.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resistivity is an intrinsic property of a material and does not depend on the conductor's dimensions (length or area) or the applied voltage. It depends only on the nature of the material and its temperature.

questions.question_text: When three resistors of 2 Ω, 3 Ω, and 5 Ω are connected in series, the total resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series combination, the total resistance is the sum of individual resistances: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃ = 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 Ω.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In series connection, resistances add up directly: R = 2 + 3 + 5 = 10 Ω. Option B is the parallel combination result. Option C incorrectly multiplies. The total resistance in series is always greater than the largest individual resistance.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, the current through each component is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all components because there is only one path for the current to take. The current does not split in a series connection. The potential difference, however, is divided among the components.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a series circuit, the current is the same through all components. There is only one path for current flow. In a parallel circuit, the current divides among the branches, but in series, it remains the same everywhere.

questions.question_text: Two resistors of 6 Ω each are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: For two equal resistors in parallel: 1/R = 1/6 + 1/6 = 2/6 = 1/3. Therefore R = 3 Ω. When two equal resistors are in parallel, the equivalent resistance is half of each individual resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In parallel: 1/R = 1/R₁ + 1/R₂ = 1/6 + 1/6 = 2/6, so R = 3 Ω. Option A adds resistances (that is for series). For two equal resistors in parallel, the result is always half the individual resistance.

questions.question_text: In a parallel circuit, the potential difference across each component is:
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, the potential difference (voltage) across each component is the same because all components are connected between the same two points. The current, however, divides among the branches inversely proportional to their resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a parallel combination, the voltage across each branch is the same. The current divides among the branches. This is in contrast to a series circuit, where the current is the same but the voltage is divided.

questions.question_text: Three resistors of 3 Ω, 6 Ω, and 9 Ω are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: 1/R = 1/3 + 1/6 + 1/9 = 6/18 + 3/18 + 2/18 = 11/18. Therefore R = 18/11 = 1.636 Ω ≈ 1.64 Ω. The equivalent resistance in parallel is always less than the smallest individual resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In parallel: 1/R = 1/3 + 1/6 + 1/9 = (6 + 3 + 2)/18 = 11/18. So R = 18/11 ≈ 1.64 Ω. Option A adds the resistances (series formula). The parallel equivalent is always less than the smallest resistance (3 Ω here).

questions.question_text: Household electrical appliances are connected in:

options.text: A combination of series and parallel

questions.explanation_correct: Household electrical appliances are connected in parallel. This ensures that each appliance gets the same voltage (220 V in India), each can be switched on/off independently, and the failure of one appliance does not affect others.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Household appliances are connected in parallel, not in series. If they were in series, switching off one appliance would break the entire circuit, and the voltage would be divided among all appliances. Parallel connection ensures independent operation.

questions.question_text: The heating effect of electric current is given by Joule's law as:
questions.explanation_correct: The heat produced by an electric current is given by H = I²Rt (Joule's law). Since V = IR, this can also be written as H = VIt. Both expressions are equivalent and correct. Another form is H = V²t/R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both H = VIt and H = I²Rt are correct expressions for the heating effect. Since V = IR, substituting gives H = (IR)(I)(t) = I²Rt. Option C (H = V/R) has incorrect units and is not a valid heat formula.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of electric power is:
questions.explanation_correct: The SI unit of electric power is the watt (W). Power is the rate at which electrical energy is consumed or dissipated. 1 watt = 1 joule per second = 1 volt × 1 ampere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Joule is the unit of energy, not power. Kilowatt-hour is the commercial unit of electrical energy. Volt is the unit of potential difference. The SI unit of electric power is the watt (W).

questions.question_text: The commercial unit of electrical energy is:
questions.explanation_correct: The commercial unit of electrical energy is the kilowatt-hour (kWh), commonly called a 'unit' of electricity. 1 kWh is the energy consumed when a 1000 W appliance runs for 1 hour. 1 kWh = 3.6 × 10⁶ J.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The commercial unit of electrical energy is the kilowatt-hour (kWh), not the watt (which is power) or the joule (which is the SI unit of energy). 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3.6 × 10⁶ J.

questions.question_text: An electric heater of resistance 20 Ω draws a current of 5 A for 30 seconds. The heat produced is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using Joule's law: H = I²Rt = (5)² × 20 × 30 = 25 × 20 × 30 = 15000 J. The heater produces 15000 joules of heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: H = I²Rt = 5² × 20 × 30 = 25 × 600 = 15000 J. Option A uses I instead of I². Option C and D have calculation errors. The heat produced is 15000 J or 15 kJ.

questions.question_text: An electric iron consumes 1000 W of power when connected to a 250 V supply. The current drawn is:
questions.explanation_correct: Using P = VI, we get I = P/V = 1000/250 = 4 A. The electric iron draws 4 amperes of current.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using P = VI, I = P/V = 1000/250 = 4 A. Option A incorrectly uses V × P. Option B incorrectly divides V by P. Option D has a calculation error.

questions.question_text: How many joules are in 1 kWh?
questions.explanation_correct: 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. This conversion is important for calculating electrical energy bills.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1 kWh = 1000 W × 1 hour = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. Option A only accounts for 1 W × 3600 s. Options B and C have incorrect calculations.

questions.question_text: A 100 W bulb is used for 10 hours. The electrical energy consumed is:
questions.explanation_correct: Energy = Power × Time = 100 W × 10 h = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh. This is equal to 1 'unit' of electricity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Energy = P × t = 100 W × 10 h = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh (1 unit of electricity). Option B incorrectly uses kW instead of W. Always convert watts to kilowatts or keep consistent units.

questions.question_text: The V-I graph for an ohmic conductor is:

options.text: A straight line passing through the origin

questions.explanation_correct: For a conductor that obeys Ohm's law (ohmic conductor), the V-I graph is a straight line passing through the origin. The slope of this line gives the resistance (R = V/I). A constant slope means constant resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An ohmic conductor has a linear relationship between V and I (V = IR with constant R). The V-I graph is therefore a straight line through the origin. A curve would indicate non-ohmic behaviour.

questions.question_text: The charge on one electron is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The charge on one electron is approximately 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ coulombs (negative charge). This is the smallest unit of charge and is called the elementary charge. 1 coulomb = 6.25 × 10¹⁸ electrons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The charge on one electron is 1.6 × 10⁻¹⁹ C. Option B has the wrong exponent sign. Option C is the mass of an electron (in kg). Option D is the number of electrons in 1 coulomb.

questions.question_text: A 4 Ω and a 12 Ω resistor are connected in parallel. The equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation_correct: 1/R = 1/4 + 1/12 = 3/12 + 1/12 = 4/12 = 1/3. Therefore R = 3 Ω. The equivalent resistance is less than the smaller resistor (4 Ω), which is always the case for parallel combinations.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In parallel: 1/R = 1/4 + 1/12 = 4/12 = 1/3, so R = 3 Ω. Alternatively, for two resistors in parallel: R = (R₁ × R₂)/(R₁ + R₂) = (4 × 12)/(4 + 12) = 48/16 = 3 Ω. Option A adds resistances (series formula).

questions.question_text: The formula for resistivity is:
questions.explanation_correct: From R = ρl/A, we get ρ = RA/l, where R is resistance, A is cross-sectional area, and l is the length of the conductor. The SI unit of resistivity is ohm-metre (Ω·m).
questions.explanation_incorrect: From the formula R = ρl/A, rearranging gives ρ = RA/l. This is the correct expression for resistivity. Option B incorrectly rearranges the formula.

questions.question_text: Two lamps rated 100 W, 220 V and 60 W, 220 V are connected in parallel to a 220 V supply. The total power consumed is:
questions.explanation_correct: When appliances are connected in parallel at their rated voltage, they consume their rated power. Total power = P₁ + P₂ = 100 + 60 = 160 W.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a parallel connection at the rated voltage, each device operates at its rated power. So total power = 100 W + 60 W = 160 W. Power adds up in parallel circuits. Option B subtracts and Option C multiplies incorrectly.

questions.question_text: The direction of conventional current is:

options.text: From negative terminal to positive terminal
From positive terminal to negative terminal
Same as the direction of electron flow

questions.explanation_correct: Conventional current flows from the positive terminal to the negative terminal of a battery (or cell) through the external circuit. This is opposite to the direction of electron flow, which is from negative to positive.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conventional current flows from positive to negative terminal (opposite to electron flow). This convention was established before the discovery of electrons. Electrons actually flow from negative to positive, but conventional current direction is still used.

questions.question_text: An electric appliance of resistance 44 Ω is connected to a 220 V supply. The current drawn and power consumed are:
questions.explanation_correct: Current I = V/R = 220/44 = 5 A. Power P = VI = 220 × 5 = 1100 W. Alternatively, P = V²/R = (220)²/44 = 48400/44 = 1100 W.
questions.explanation_incorrect: I = V/R = 220/44 = 5 A and P = VI = 220 × 5 = 1100 W. Option B doubles the current. Options C and D have incorrect power calculations.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an advantage of connecting appliances in parallel?

options.text: All appliances get the same voltage
Current is the same through all appliances

questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel connection, all appliances receive the same voltage (equal to the supply voltage), each appliance can be operated independently, and the failure of one does not affect others. These are the main advantages of parallel wiring in households.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The key advantage of parallel connection is that all appliances get the same voltage. In series, voltage would be divided. Also, appliances can be switched on/off independently in parallel. The current divides (not same) in parallel.

questions.question_text: The SI unit of electric charge is the ampere.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The SI unit of electric charge is the coulomb (C), not the ampere. The ampere is the SI unit of electric current. 1 coulomb = 1 ampere × 1 second.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The SI unit of charge is the coulomb (C), not the ampere (A). The ampere measures current (rate of flow of charge). 1 C = 1 A × 1 s.

questions.question_text: According to Ohm's law, resistance is directly proportional to voltage.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Ohm's law states that voltage (V) is directly proportional to current (I), with resistance (R) as the constant of proportionality: V = IR. Resistance is a property of the conductor and does not depend on the applied voltage for ohmic conductors.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ohm's law states V is proportional to I (V = IR). Resistance is the constant of proportionality, not a variable that depends on voltage. For ohmic conductors, R remains constant regardless of the voltage applied.

questions.question_text: The equivalent resistance in a parallel combination is always less than the smallest individual resistance.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. In a parallel combination, the equivalent resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance. This is because adding more resistors in parallel provides more paths for current flow, reducing the overall resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. In parallel, each additional resistor provides another path for current, so the total resistance decreases. The equivalent resistance is always less than any individual resistance in the parallel combination.

questions.question_text: Electric fuse works on the heating effect of electric current.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. An electric fuse is a safety device that works on the heating effect of current. It is made of a wire with a low melting point. When current exceeds the safe limit, the fuse wire heats up excessively and melts, breaking the circuit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electric fuses indeed work on the heating effect of current. When excessive current flows, the fuse wire (made of a material with low melting point) heats up and melts, disconnecting the circuit to prevent damage.

questions.question_text: Resistivity of a conductor increases with increase in its length.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Resistivity is a property of the material itself and does not depend on the dimensions of the conductor. It depends only on the nature of the material and temperature. Resistance increases with length, but resistivity does not.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Resistivity (ρ) is an intrinsic property of the material and does not change with the length or area of the conductor. Only resistance (R = ρl/A) increases with length. Resistivity depends only on the material type and temperature.

questions.question_text: Electric current is measured using an instrument called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: An ammeter is the instrument used to measure electric current in a circuit. It is always connected in series with the component through which the current is to be measured.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'ammeter'. An ammeter measures electric current and is connected in series. A voltmeter measures potential difference and is connected in parallel.

questions.question_text: The relationship V = IR is known as ___ law.
questions.explanation_correct: The relationship V = IR is known as Ohm's law, named after the German physicist Georg Simon Ohm. It states that the potential difference across a conductor is directly proportional to the current flowing through it at constant temperature.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Ohm's'. Ohm's law, V = IR, is one of the most fundamental laws in electricity. It was discovered by Georg Simon Ohm in 1827.

questions.question_text: In a series circuit, the total resistance is the ___ of individual resistances.
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, the total (equivalent) resistance is the sum of all individual resistances: R_total = R₁ + R₂ + R₃ + ... The total resistance is always greater than the largest individual resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sum'. In a series combination, resistances add up directly: R = R₁ + R₂ + R₃. In parallel, the reciprocals of resistances add up.

questions.question_text: The formula for electric power is P = ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Electric power is defined as the rate of doing work or the rate of consuming electrical energy. The formula is P = VI, where V is the potential difference and I is the current. Other equivalent forms are P = I²R and P = V²/R.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'VI'. Electric power P = VI (voltage times current). This can also be written as P = I²R or P = V²/R by substituting Ohm's law.

questions.question_text: Potential difference is measured using an instrument called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: A voltmeter is the instrument used to measure the potential difference (voltage) between two points in a circuit. It is always connected in parallel across the component whose voltage is to be measured.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'voltmeter'. A voltmeter measures potential difference and is connected in parallel. It has a very high resistance to draw minimal current from the circuit.

questions.question_text: The resistance of a conductor is given by R = ρl/A, where ρ is called the ___ of the material.
questions.explanation_correct: In the formula R = ρl/A, ρ (rho) is called the resistivity (or specific resistance) of the material. It is a characteristic property of the material and its SI unit is ohm-metre (Ω·m).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'resistivity'. Resistivity (ρ) is a material property that quantifies how strongly the material opposes current flow. It is measured in Ω·m and differs for different materials.

questions.question_text: If one of three bulbs connected in series fuses, what happens to the other two?
questions.explanation_correct: In a series circuit, there is only one path for current. If one bulb fuses (breaks), the circuit becomes open and current stops flowing. All the remaining bulbs will also stop glowing because no current passes through them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a series circuit, all components share the same current path. If any component fails, the circuit is broken and current stops flowing through the entire circuit. This is a major disadvantage of series connections.

questions.question_text: A copper wire has resistance R. Another copper wire of same length but twice the cross-sectional area will have resistance:
questions.explanation_correct: Since R = ρl/A, if the length and material are the same but the area is doubled, the new resistance = ρl/(2A) = R/2. Resistance is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Using R = ρl/A, doubling the area gives R_new = ρl/(2A) = R/2. Resistance is inversely proportional to cross-sectional area: thicker wires have lower resistance. This is why power lines use thick wires.

questions.question_text: Which of the following appliances does NOT work on the heating effect of current?
questions.explanation_correct: An electric fan works on the magnetic effect of electric current (an electric motor converts electrical energy to mechanical energy). Electric iron, heater, and toaster all work on the heating effect of current to produce heat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An electric fan uses a motor that operates on the magnetic effect of current, not the heating effect. It converts electrical energy into rotational (mechanical) energy. The iron, heater, and toaster all convert electrical energy into heat.

questions.question_text: The heat produced in a resistor is given by H = I²Rt. This is known as ___'s law of heating.
questions.explanation_correct: The relationship H = I²Rt is known as Joule's law of heating, named after James Prescott Joule. It states that the heat produced in a resistor is directly proportional to the square of the current, the resistance, and the time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'Joule'. Joule's law of heating (H = I²Rt) describes how electrical energy is converted to heat energy in a resistor. It was formulated by James Prescott Joule.

questions.question_text: In a parallel combination, the total current divides among the branches but the ___ remains the same across each branch.
questions.explanation_correct: In a parallel circuit, all branches are connected across the same two points, so the potential difference (voltage) across each branch is the same. The current divides among the branches in inverse proportion to their resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'voltage' (or potential difference). In a parallel circuit, voltage is common to all branches while current divides. In series, current is common while voltage divides.

questions.question_text: 1 kilowatt-hour is equal to 3600 joules.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3,600,000 J = 3.6 × 10⁶ J, not 3600 J. 3600 J = 1 Wh (watt-hour). The factor of 1000 (from kilo) makes a significant difference.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 1 kWh is not 3600 J. The correct conversion is 1 kWh = 1000 W × 3600 s = 3.6 × 10⁶ J. The value 3600 J equals only 1 watt-hour, not 1 kilowatt-hour.
